channel.title: Help with fractions
channel.description: how do i convert 0.316666666... (forever) into a fraction. answer as fast as possible please :) thankyou in advance XD

item.title: Help with fractions
item.dc:creator: @anonsage anonsage
item.description:
@anonsage wrote:

While reading this I came up with another way to find the fraction form of .316666…

Notice the 6666…repeating, I’ll assume you know that 2/3= .666666…
But, the decimal you want is .35 smaller than 2/3.
.35 = 35/100 = 7/20

So, you have 2/3 - 7/20 = 40/60 - 21/60 = 19/60 Woot!

Read full topic

since .333 repeated is equal to 1/3, it will be a bit smaller than 1/3. It will probably be like
19/60. ^_-

item.title: Help with fractions
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

we’ll call the decimal, x

x = 0.316666666
100x = 31.666…
10000x = 3166.66…
9900x = 3135
x = 3135/9900

your fraction is 3135/9900

yay, i love maths!!

edit: that cancels to 19/60, so Bob Dole did actually get it before me (luck I say, you just did trail-and-error :p)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

if you ahve a graphical calculator you can plot 1/x and tell it to solve, even though you cant type in an infinite number of decimal places the calculator gets the idea( or at least mine does)

Read full topic

item.title: Help with fractions
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

The difficult part is that a lot of calculators don’t have functions to handle fractional forms, and I’ve always found that simply typing in a repeating, non-terminating decimal is not recognized by calculators as the same thing.

However, you can make some logical assumptions from what you do have. Your decimal is close to, but slightly smaller than, 1/3. You denominator, obviously, need to then be a multiple of 3, and the numerator needs to be a bit less than 1/3 of the denominator. Going through various possibilities, such as 4/15, 9/30, I determined that 0.3166666… is 19/60.

This is kinda long winded, but unfortunately I don’t know an easier way of doing it.

Read full topic
